facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 89 of 1953 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 89 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal from High Court of Judicature at Madras judgment dated 28th March 1949 in Appeal No. 654 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 28th day of March, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Madras in Appeal No. 654 of 1945,

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from District Judge Bellary judgment dated 23rd July 1945 in Original Suit No. 17 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and Decree dated the 23rd day of July, 1945, of the Court of the District Judge, Bellary, in Original Suit No. 17 of 1944.

facts.text: Original suit commenced by plaintiff respondent in District Judge Bellary, Original Suit No. 17 of 1944 for title to one-half share of land and possession after partition with defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit, companymenced by the plaintiff respondent, in the Court of the District Judge of Bellary, being Original Suit No. 17 of 1944, for establishment of his title to one-half share

facts.text: Suit filed on 18th July 1944 by plaintiff against Chenabasavana as defendant No. 1 and his vendor as defendant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th July, 1944, the plaintiff brought the present suit against Chenabasavana as defendant No. I for recovery of a demarcated half-share of the disputed property after partition

facts.text: Land in suit has area of a little over 9 acres, specifically 9 acres 49 cents of wet land.

anchor.surface_text: The land in suit, which has an area of a little over 9 acres, was admittedly the property of one Basappa who died some time before 1918

facts.text: Land was property of Basappa who died before 1918 leaving three daughters Paramma, Pompamma and Hampamma.

anchor.surface_text: a little over 9 acres, was admittedly the property of one Basappa who died some time before 1918, leaving three daughters, to wit Paramma, Pompamma and Hampamma.

facts.text: Under settlement evidenced by Exhibits P-2 (1918) and P-3 (1919), three sisters got 15 to 16 acres wet land in absolute right.

anchor.surface_text: Under a settlement entered into with the immediate reversioner of Basappa which is evidenced by two registered deeds-Exhibits P-2 and P-3-executed respectively in the years 1918 and 1919,

facts.text: Hampamma took her one-third share in the lands.

anchor.surface_text: the three sisters got about 15 to 16 acres of wet land in absolute right. Hampamma subsequently took away her one- third share in these lands

facts.text: Subject matter of suit is two-thirds share comprising 9 acres 49 cents wet land enjoyed by Paramma and Pompamma.

anchor.surface_text: and Pompamma companytinued to enjoy the remaining two-thirds share of the property and it is this two-thirds ,share companyprising 9 acres 49 cents of wet land which forms the subject-matter

facts.text: Pompamma married Nagana Gowd, gave birth to two sons Siddalingana and Chenabasavana, died in 1923.

anchor.surface_text: Pompamma married one Nagana Gowd and after giving birth to two sons to wit Siddalingana and Chenabasa- vana, she died in the year 1923.

facts.text: Pompamma's share in lands devolved upon her two sons, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that her share in the lands mentioned above devolved upon these two sons.

facts.text: On 22nd June 1923, Paramma executed deed of gift conveying her share in suit property to two sons of Pompamma.

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd June, 1923, Paramma executed a deed of gift in favour of the two sons of her sister by which she companyveyed to the latter her own share in the. suit property.

facts.text: After gift, two sons owned entirety of 9 acres 49 cents land jointly.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the two sons of Pompamma got the entirety of the 9 acres 49 cents of land which as owned jointly by their mother and their mothers sister Paramma.

facts.text: Siddalingana, elder son, died in 1924.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly after this gift was made, Siddalingana, the elder son of Pompamma, died in the year 1924

facts.text: Plaintiff's case: Siddalingana's half-share devolved on father Nagana under Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: and the plaintiffs case is that his half-share in the disputed property devolved upon his father Nagkna under the Hindu law of inheritance.

facts.text: Paramma continued to possess entirety of land on behalf of younger son Chenabasavana, admitted.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted however that Paramma companytinued to possess the entirety of the land on behalf of the younger son Chenabasavana who is defendant No. 1 in the suit

facts.text: Lease deed Exhibit D-1 and counterpart D-2 dated 25th August 1926 executed between Paramma and Nagana as guardian of infant Chenabasavana, leasing entire property to Paramma for 12 years at Rs. 500/year.

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th August, 1946, there was a lease deed Exhibit D-1, and its companynter part Exhibit D-2, executed by and between Paramma on the one hand and Nagana as the father and guardian [...] 12 years at a rental of Rs. 500 a year.

facts.text: Rent receipts Exhibits D-4 (1927) and D-4-1 (1932) passed by Nagana to Paramma on behalf of Chenabasavana.

anchor.surface_text: Two rent receipts passed by Nagana to Paramma in token of the receipt of rents, reserved by this lease, on behalf of Chenabasavana have been proved in this case, Exhibits D-4 and D4-1, and they are of the years 1927 and 1932 respectively.

facts.text: In 1934 Nagana instituted suit as guardian of Chenabasavana in Munsif Court Hospet for Rs. 500 rent from Paramma, decreed ex parte, discharged by Exhibit D-3 dated 14th November 1934.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1934 Nagana instituted a suit as guardian of his infant son Chenabasavana in the Munsifs Court at Hospet to recover a -sum of Rs. 500 as rent from Paramma [...] executed by Nagana, which companytains a recital that as Paramma had borrowed much money [...] dated the 14th of November, 1934,

facts.text: Nagana became financially involved near 1935, undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence and number disputed, that near about this time Nagana became financially involved

facts.text: On 27th August 1935, Nagana executed mortgage by conditional sale of half-share of disputed land to defendant No. 2 for Rs. 3000.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 27th of August, 1935, he executed a deed of mortgage by companyditional sale in respect of half-share of the disputed land in favour of defendant No. 2 to secure an advance of Rs. 3,000.

facts.text: Mortgage recited half-share devolved on mortgagor on death of Siddalingana and he was in possession.

anchor.surface_text: The document recites that the half-share of the land which was kept as. security devolved upon the mortgagor on the death of his son Siddalingana and that he was in possession of the same.

facts.text: On 16th July 1936, Nagana sold mortgaged property to mortgagee by Exhibit P-6 for Rs. 3000.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th July, 1936, Nagana sold the mortgaged property by,a deed of sale  Exhibit P-6  to the mortgagee himself or a companysideration of Rs. 3,000

facts.text: Purchaser did not obtain possession of property.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the purchaser did number and companyld number obtain possession -of the property at any time since then

facts.text: On 2nd May 1944, defendant No. 2 sold property to plaintiff by conveyance Exhibit P-1.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 2nd May, 1944, he sold the property to the plaintiff by a companyveyance which is Exhibit P-1.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 contested suit claiming joint tenancy with survivorship so interest passed to him, not father.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial defence put forward was of a two-fold character. It was companytended in the first place that under the deed of gift executed by Paramma in favour of defendant No. I and his deceased brother Siddalingana, the donees became joint tenants with rights of survivorship

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 claimed title by adverse possession as plaintiff never in possession.

anchor.surface_text: The other and the more material defence raised was that the plaintiffs suit was barred, as he was never in possession of the property and the defendant No. 1 acquired a good title by adverse possession.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed suit holding no right to Nagana, disclaimed by lease etc., and adverse possession established.

anchor.surface_text: Both these points were decided against the plaintiff by the learned District Judge who tried the suit. It was held that the deed of gift executed by Paramma companyferred numberright on Nagana as the heir of his son [...] the plaintiffs suit was bound to fail as he or his predecessors were never in possession

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court, held tenants in common, Nagana inherited, adverse possession ended in 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held, differing from the trial Court, that the two sons of Pompamma took their shares [...] as tenants in companymon and number as joint tenants [...] the adverse possession of the son forthwith came to an end.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, restored trial court decree, holding adverse possession continued from 1926 uninterrupted.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the view taken by the learned Judges of the High Court is number proper and cannot be sustained. The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.
under article 133 of the Constitution read with sections 109 and 110 of the Civil Procedure Code.

issues.text: Whether under the deed of gift executed by Paramma the donees (defendant No.1 and Siddalingana) became joint tenants with rights of survivorship such that Siddalingana's interest devolved upon defendant No.1 and not upon his father Nagana

anchor.surface_text: under the deed of gift executed by Paramma in favour of defendant No. I and his deceased brother Siddalingana, the donees became joint tenants with rights of survivorship Consequently on the death of Siddalingana his interest devolved upon defendant No. 1 and

issues.text: Whether the plaintiff's suit was barred as he or his predecessors were never in possession within 12 years of suit and defendant No.1 acquired good title by adverse possession

anchor.surface_text: the defendant No. 1 acquired a good title by adverse possession. Both these points were decided against the plaintiff by the learned District Judge who tried the suit. It was held that the deed of gift executed by Paramma conferred no right on Nagana as the heir of his son and such rights if any were specifically disclaimed by Nagana by the lease deed and also by the receipts which he granted to Paramma as the guardian of his minor son. It was held further that the plaintiffs suit was bound to fail as he or his predecessors were never in possession of the property within 12 years from the date of the suit.

issues.text: Whether actual ouster was proved rebutting the presumption that possession of one co-owner is on behalf of the other co-owner

anchor.surface_text: As the plaintiff purports to derive his title from Nagana, he can be said to have established his title as a co-owner with defendant No. I and this being the position, the presumption of law would be that the possession of one co-owner was on behalf of the other also unless actual ouster was proved.

issues.text: Whether the adverse possession from 1926 was interrupted by Nagana's 1935 mortgage asserting his title as joint owner

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the possession of a co-sharer has become adverse to the other co-sharer as a result of ouster, the mere assertion of his joint title by the dispossessed co-sharer would not interrupt the running of adverse possession.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff established title as co-owner via Nagana, presumption possession on behalf of other unless ouster proved

arguments.claim: Acts in lease by father as guardian asserted exclusive title of son, denying own co-owner rights, proves ouster

anchor.surface_text: In granting the lease on behalf of the infant the father definitely asserted the exclusive title of his son to the property and by implication denied his own rights as a coowner thereto.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that Nagana consented to such exclusion is immaterial. There can be in law, under certain circumstances, adverse possession with the consent of the true owner.

arguments.claim: Once ouster, mere assertion of joint title by dispossessed does not interrupt adverse possession; needs re-entry or resumption

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the, possession of a co-sharer has become adverse to the other co-sharer as a result of ouster, the mere assertion of his joint title by the dispossessed co-sharer would not interrupt the running of adverse possession.

arguments.claim: No interruption as no re-entry possible (lessee in possession), rent receipts/suit as guardian affirmed minor's title

anchor.surface_text: Resumption of physical possession or re-entry upon the property was absolutely out of the question, as the property was in the possession of a lessee. The lease, it should be noted, was executed in 1926 and we have two rent receipts of the years 1927 and 1932 respectively

arguments.claim: 1935 mortgage was father's personal act qua proprietor, not as guardian; does not bind son or change possession

anchor.surface_text: The fathers acts in connection with the lease were entirely in his capacity as guardian of his son. In the eye of the law they were the acts of the son, but the creation of the mortage in 1935 was not the act of the father on behalf of his son,

holdings.text: After the death of Siddalingana, Nagana became a co-owner of the disputed property with his minor son Chenabasavana.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ayyangar appearing in support of the appeal has not pressed before us the contention that was raised on behalf of his client in the Courts below, that as the two brothers took the property as joint tenants and not as tenants in common, the interest of Siddalingana passed on his death to his brother, the defendant No. 1, and not to Nagana. We must take it therefore that after the death of Siddalingana, Nagana became a co-owner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint tenancy contention not pressed before Supreme Court, therefore accepted that donees took as tenants in common and father inherited son's share.

holdings.text: The presumption of law is that the possession of one co-owner is on behalf of the other unless actual ouster is proved.

anchor.surface_text: As the plaintiff purports to derive his title from Nagana, he can be said to have established his title as a co-owner with defendant No. 1 and this being the position, the presumption of law would be that the possession of one co-owner was on behalf of the other also unless actual ouster was proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff derives title from Nagana who became co-owner; presumption applies requiring proof of ouster by defendant.

holdings.text: Acts and conduct of the father in connection with the lease deed of 1926 asserted the exclusive title of his son to the property and by implication denied his own rights as a co-owner thereto.

anchor.surface_text: But the acts and conduct of the father in connection with the lease deed of 1926 and the subsequent granting of receipts in terms thereof undoubtedly point to something more than mere non-participation in the enjoyment of profits of the property on absence of objection to the exclusive enjoyment thereof by Paramma on behalf of the infant. In granting the lease on behalf of the infant the father definitely asserted the exclusive title of his son to the property and by implication denied his own rights as a coowner thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Father as guardian granting lease on behalf of infant denied own co-owner rights, proving ouster.

holdings.text: In law the possession of the lessee is the possession of the lessor and consequently ever since 1926 when Paramma began to possess the property as a lessee in terms of the lease deed, her possession in law was the possession of the infant alone to the exclusion of Nagana, the father.

anchor.surface_text: In law the possession of the lessee is the possession of the lessor and consequently ever since 1926 when Paramma began to possess the property as a lessee in terms of the lease deed, her possession in law was the possession of the infant alone to the exclusion of Nagana, the father.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal principle that lessee's possession attributes to lessor (minor), excluding father from 1926.

holdings.text: There can be in law, under certain circumstances, adverse possession with the consent of the true owner.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that Nagana consented to such exclusion is immaterial. There can be in law, under certain circumstances, adverse possession with the consent of the true owner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nagana's consent to exclusion immaterial; illustrated by invalid transfers where possession becomes adverse despite consent.

holdings.text: Once the possession of a co-sharer has become adverse to the other co-sharer as a result of ouster, the mere assertion of his joint title by the dispossessed co-sharer would not interrupt the running of adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the possession of a co-sharer has become adverse to the other co-sharer as a result of ouster, the mere assertion of his joint title by the dispossessed co-sharer would not interrupt the running of adverse possession. He must actually and effectively break up the exclusive possession of his co-sharer by re-entry upon the property or by resuming possession in such manner as it was possible to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1935 mortgage mere assertion without re-entry or change in possession; rent receipts and suit as guardian continued affirming minor's title.

holdings.text: The father's acts in connection with the lease were entirely in his capacity as guardian of his son and were the acts of the son, but the creation of the mortgage in 1935 was the personal act of the father qua proprietor and not on behalf of his son.

anchor.surface_text: The fathers acts in connection with the lease were entirely in his capacity as guardian of his son. In the eye of the law they were the acts of the son, but the creation of the mortage in 1935 was not the act of the father on behalf of his son, it was the personal act of the father himself qua coproprietor of the son and the interest of one being adverse to the other such acts could not be held to be acts of the son performed through the father.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes guardian acts (binding minor) from personal acts (do not bind or affect minor's possession).

holdings.text: Defendant No. 1 acquired title by adverse possession from 1926 uninterrupted; plaintiff's suit is barred.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the view taken by the learned Judges of the High Court is not proper and cannot be sustained. The result is that the appeal is allowed the judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ouster from 1926 via lease as guardian; no interruption by 1935 mortgage; possession continued exclusively for minor beyond 12 years.

Lessee's Possession is Lessor's Possession support

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and decree of the High Court set aside; judgment and decree of the District Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ayyangar appearing in support of the appeal has not pressed before us the contention that was raised on behalf of his client in the Courts below, that as the two brothers took the property as joint tenants and not as tenants in common, the interest of Siddalingana passed on his death to his brother, the defendant No. 1, and not to Nagana. We must take it therefore that after the death of Siddalingana, Nagana became a co-owner
The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.

As the plaintiff purports to derive his title from Nagana, he can be said to have established his title as a co-owner with defendant No. 1 and this being the position, the presumption of law would be that the possession of one co-owner was on behalf of the other also unless actual ouster was proved.
The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 that father's 1926 lease acts asserted son's exclusive title and denied own rights supports concept c13 of guardian's denial asserting minor's title and binding minor
Holding h3 on 1926 lease acts asserting son's exclusive title addresses issue i6 whether Nagana's 1926 lease acts bound minor as guardian asserting title

anchor.surface_text: But the acts and conduct of the father in connection with the lease deed of 1926 and the subsequent granting of receipts in terms thereof undoubtedly point to something more than mere non-participation in the enjoyment of profits of the property on absence of objection to the exclusive enjoyment thereof by Paramma on behalf of the infant. In granting the lease on behalf of the infant the father definitely asserted the exclusive title of his son to the property and by implication denied his own rights as a coowner thereto.
The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: In law the possession of the lessee is the possession of the lessor and consequently ever since 1926 when Paramma began to possess the property as a lessee in terms of the lease deed, her possession in law was the possession of the infant alone to the exclusion of Nagana, the father.
The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the possession of a co-sharer has become adverse to the other co-sharer as a result of ouster, the mere assertion of his joint title by the dispossessed co-sharer would not interrupt the running of adverse possession. He must actually and effectively break up the exclusive possession of his co-sharer by re-entry upon the property or by resuming possession in such manner as it was possible to do.
The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.
The result is that the appeal is allowed the ,judgment and decree of the High Court are set aside and those of the District Judge restored.
